subject: RE: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... There s no need to use private methods to test this. Assuming the code paths for the two constructors converge at some point immediately after the input
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Steven Taschuk [mailto:staschuk@...]
>
> So, I decide I want a partwise constructor
> public GregorianDate( int year, int month, int date )
> which will throw IllegalArgumentException if any of these
> constraints are violated. I write some tests to express the
> expectation of such exceptions, watch them fail, write the
> constructor, watch them pass, go for a beer.
>
> Now I want a parsing constructor
> public GregorianDate( String s ) throws
> DateParseException which will parse strings in ISO 8601
> format (such as "2002-12-18"), throwing a DateParseException
> if the string is malformed or if the constraints on valid
> dates are violated. I factor the constraint checking out of
> the partwise constructor and into private methods so it can
> be reused by this new constructor, and now the problem arises.


There's no need to use private methods to test this. Assuming the code
paths for the two constructors converge at some point immediately after
the input String is parsed, you can test the parsing code and the date
processing code separately.

To test the parsing code, you would compare instances created partwise
with instances created through parsing for equality, or assert that they
throw identical exceptions. Once you know that the two constructors
behave similarly across a set of reasonable variations, you can
concentrate on behavioral tests with just one of the constructor forms.

You can probably make things a little easier by creating a method that
converts any partwise specification into a String formatted
specification. That way you only define your data variations in one
place and convert on the fly for the other constructor.

I'd also make a bunch of helper methods, such as one that takes a
partwise date specification and an expected exception, and then
instantiates using both constructors, asserting that both cause the
expected exception to be thrown. That way you're not replicating a lot
of code.

- Mike
